titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: My night’s rest was divided into two parts, the first terminating just before daylight and the second after sunrise, and I had strength this morning to walk round the short Railway Square.— I answered the Letter from William Slade, though it will not probably be to his satisfaction— His project is for the improvement of popular Education a very excellent design, but in my apprehension, there is but one improvement, for popular education, desirable for the improvement of man and of his happiness upon Earth, not I fear included, in the operations of Mr. Slade, however embraced in his ultimate purposes. It is not yet undertaken and I fear will not be for many years, though I cannot doubt, that it will be undertaken and accomplished at some future day— I received also a Letter from Mr. Henry Gassett including an Extract of one to him, from Mr. William H. Seward of the State of New York, to whom he had sent a copy of the new Edition of my writings upon the Masonic Controversy— My wife received two small boxes of Honey as a present from Mr. Wm. Ellis of Dedham, for which she returned a Letter of thanks— It is on the part of Mr. Ellis, a testimonial of his thanks for the services I have rendered him in recovering Pensions for several of his friends, and particularly for the heirs of Peter Dunbar— I rode this afternoon with Mrs. John Adams, and Miss Mary Cutts, to Braintree, returning by Dr. Storrs meeting House and the Weymouth Turnpike. Mrs. Charles and her daughter took Tea and spent the Evening here. My wife was not well enough to ride with us this day. I read, Dupuis, upon Universal Religion, and the anonymous, Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— My Son was here in the Eveg—

Morning visit from Joshua Leavitt, who has just ceased from being the Editor of the Emancipator Newspaper. I walked round the short Square before dinner; and towards Evening rode to Milton with my wife, Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts. I continue reading Dupuis Universelle Religion and the Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— Two works of a totally different character but tending to one result, and both equally unsatisfactory.

J. Wingate Thornton, Cousin of Miss Cutts visited her here this morning. and this evening Mrs. John Adams and her daughter, My Son and his daughter Louisa Catherine and Miss Cutts, went to Boston to witness the Theatrical performances of Mrs. Bishop an Italian Prima Donna now exhibiting in that City. They returned about Midnight home, much pleased with their entertainment—

In taking my walk round the short Square this morning I met Mr. Lunt who told me Mr. William R. Alger was to be ordained as Minister of the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society in Roxbury next Wednesday at 1/2 past 2. oclock in the afternoon. That the first Congregational Church in Quincy was among the Churches invited to take part in this Ordination and he asked my consent to propose to the Church as a Delegate to attend with him which I gave the answer being conditional in case the state of my health should admit. I rode this afternoon with my wife, Mrs. Charles
Adams, to Braintree— Evening visits from Joseph. H. and John Quincy who has just returned from Norfolk. I received a Letter from President Edward Everett, proposing to me as Chairman of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University for visiting the Astronomical Observatory to appoint an early day for the visitation; concerning which I must consult Mr. Josiah Quincy and Abbott Lawrence—

We have had a long series of warm and dry weather during which my state of health has been tolerable and promising. Last night my rest was much broken and I find myself very weak this day— Mr. Lunt preached at home in the morning from Nehemiah 6.3. “And I sent messengers unto them saying I am doing a great work so that I cannot come down why should the work cease whilst I leave it and come down to you”— The stress of this Discourse was upon the words “I am doing a great work,” which Mr. Lunt applied to his hearers, who had all he said “a great work” to do— But the Discourse Historical— The great work which Nehemiah was doing was of a character different from that which Christian hearers of the present day are called to perform,— Into the historical portion of the text he did not enter very deeply only mentioning that Nehemiah was Cup Bearer of ArtaxerxesKing of Persia by whose authority Nehemiah was authorized to accomplish the rebuilding of the Temple of Jerusalem. first commanded by Sirus. after the Babylonian captivity— This was a most interesting period of the History of the Tribe of Judah consequent to its extinction as a separate Kingdom from that of the Ten Tribes otherwise called the Samaritans. It would require a deeper insight into the History of the two Kingdoms than was taken by Mr. Lunt. And among other things it would require a development of the
rivalship and mutual hatred between the Kingdoms of Judah and of Samaria, to which there is repeated allusion in the new Testament but no full explanation of it given. The Kingdom of Judah was partially restored and the Temple of Jerusalem reconstructed until finally destroyed by the Romans—the Kingdom of Samaria was never restored nor is it known what became of the remnant of the Children of Israel which had separated from the Descendants of Judah— this part of the sacred History is left in great obscurity and there have been Historical inquirers who pretend to discover traces of that people among the Tribes of North American Indians— Mr. Lunts Afternoon Sermon was from Phillippians 4.12. “I know how to abound”—which is only a part of the verse, the whole of which is, “I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound, everywhere, and in all things, I am instructed, both to be full, and to be hungry, both to abound, and to suffer need.” There was nothing particularly remarkable in this Discourse. I received a Pamphlet entitled Christianity and Slavery. A review of Drs. Fuller and Wayland on domestic Slavery—by William Hague a Baptist Minister in Boston Pastor of a Church in Bedford Street— Drs. Fuller and Wayland are also Baptist Ministers one of Beauford South Carolina the other of Providence Rhode Island where he is President of Brown University— In this controversy Dr. Fuller, sustains the cause of Slavery and Wayland betrays the cause of Christianity—as is honestly shown, by Mr. Hague—

After two sleepless nights I had one tolerably quiet with rain and a change of temperature in the atmosphere from warm to cool and after six days without a visit from either of my Mulatto Barbers, I was
finally shaved this afternoon by my Sons man Michael— To this state of dependence I am reduced, from the inability to shave myself and to the want of punctuality in other Shavers. I rode this afternoon with Mrs. Charles Adams Miss Cutts and my Granddaughter, and called at Mr. Josiah Quincys— I agreed with him to propose to the other Members of the Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University for visiting the Observatory at Cambridge—to fix upon Tuesday the 14th. of this month for that visitation, for which purpose I promised to go to Boston tomorrow and confer with Mr. Abbott Lawrence—and any other Member of the Committee that I may find there— The appointment of the day is the duty of the President of the University, but Mr. Everett consulting my particular convenience has referred it to me—a somewhat troublesome task.

I had a tolerable quiet night and slept till daylight— This morning, after breakfast I called upon Mr. Lunt who agreed to take an early dinner with me to morrow and go with me in my carriage to the Mount Pleasant Congregational Church to the Ordination of the Rev Mr. Alger which is to take place at half past two oclock P.M. but the Meeting of the Counsil is to be at half past one, and we are to dine at twelve and to go at half past twelve, so as to reach the place by the time of the meeting of the Counsil— I then went in the Carriage with my wife, Miss Cutts, and Mary Louisa, to Boston the Ladies leaving the Carriage at the Corner of Summer Street— I then went first to the Counting House of Abbott and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street, where I found Mr. Abbott Lawrence but he was going next Monday to New York.
from whence he will not return till the end the week, I therefore agreed with him to request President Everett to fix on Tuesday the 21st. of this month at ten oclock in the morning as the time for the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University to visit the Observatory for which Mr. Lawrence promised to give due notice to the other Members of the Committee with the exception of President Quincy, whom I agreed to notify. The other Members are David Sears, who is at Newport, Theodore Lyman, Robert— T— Paine, J. Ingersoll Bowditch, and Francis Peabody of Salem— Mr. Abbott Lawrence has very recently made a donation of fifty thousand dollars to Harvard University for the establishment of a Professorship of Practical Science, for which I this day offered him my personal hearty thanks, and told him that if I had not given them to him before in writing, they had been in my heart from the first moment I had heard of this more than princely munificence. I next proceeded to my sons Office No 23 Court Street, where I found him, with Mr. Charles Sumner— Mr. Shepherd one of the Editors of the Boston Daily Whig came in with several Newspapers and spoke of some trouble in the Whig Party at New Bedford—which however was not fully explained to me— A more important incident is stated in some of this days newspapers that is that on Monday the 30th. of August a fight occurred at Drummond Town, Accomac County, Virginia between Thomas. H. Bayly, the member of Congress from the Accomac District and Mr. Finney one of the Representatives of the County in the Legislature of the State growing out of the late Division of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in which Bayly, shot Finney in the thigh The excitement is said to be intense—Bayly was imprisoned in the Jail a part of Monday, has been compelled to leave the County, and on
Friday the 3d. September took passage in the Boat for Baltimore— The excitement is said to have prevailed to such an extent that on Monday one of the magistrates of the County went on the Bench armed with a pair of Revolving Pistols and a Bowie knife. But what the cause of the excitement was, except late division of the Methodist Episcopal Church, is not told. From my Sons Office I called at Dr. Bigelows House on Summer Street;—but he was not at home— I met the Ladies here, and went to Dr Frothinghams, but Mrs. Frothingham went this day to Medford and the Dr. himself was not at home— After waiting for his return till some time past one oclock we returned to Quincy, to dinner. After which, I took a walk round the short Square and in the Eveg. my son and his Wife, with Louisa Catherine were here in Mr. Beale and his daughter Ann, also paid us an hour’s visit—

A quiet night and Sleep till daylight— at twelve oclock, noon Mr. Lunt took an early dinner with me, immediately after which, we went together in my Carriage to the Church of the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society at Roxbury where we attended the ordination of the Reverend Wm. Alger— We found the Council assembled, and the . . . of the Delegates invited to the ceremony calling over by the Rev John Pierce D.D. Pastor of the Church at Brookline acting as Scribe— The Churches invited were more numerous than usual; and there were in attendance as many as forty Pastors, each with one lay Delegate— When they were all called over Dr. Pierce observed that before proceeding to the ordination it was usual for the person to be ordained to produce some testimonials of his
qualifications for the Office of the Ministry, but Mr. Alger observing that he was known to many of the gentlemen in attendance, he had not thought it necessary to obtain any testimonials to his qualifications. No objection however was made to proceeding— Dr. Pierce then observed that it was also usual, for the person about to be Ordained to give some account of his opinions and the Doctrines of his Faith, and he enquired if any person desired this of Mr. Alger. A motion was accordingly made that he should be requested to give such an account. An Amendment was proposed to the Motion to substitute the word required instead of requested. And upon taking the vote the word requested was retained— And upon the vote with the word requested the answers in the affirmative and negative were so nearly equal that the moderator declared he was unable to determine on which side the decision had been— He then proposed that those who were for requesting the candidate, to declare his opinions should show their sense by rising in their seats whereupon twenty two members rose. after which the members against making the request rose and they were nine in number. Whereupon Dr. Pierce declared the majority were in favor of making the request which he accordingly did Mr. Alger then summed up his Faith in the belief of the existence of a God, the immortality of the Soul, and the responsibility of Man to his Maker in a future World. No further inquiries were made and the vote was immediately taken to proceed to the Ordination. They began with an Anthem, followed by an introductory Prayer by the Revd. F. D. Huntington of Boston whose Ordination I attended as Delegate from the Church some three or four years since. In the order of exercises it was said that selections from Scriptures should be read by the Rev Nathl.
Hall, but this part was omitted— A Hymn by the Rev Henry Ware Junior was then sung, and a Sermon was preached by the Rev Samuel. K. Lothrop Pastor of the Brattle Street Church in Boston. His text was from 2 Corinthians 2–16. “Who is sufficient for these things”—and his argument was that a minister of the Gospel to be fitted for his Office, should be sufficient for all things— The Sermon was succeeded by the Prayer of Ordination by the Rev Horatio Alger an uncle of the candidate— Then came the Charge, by the Rev Ephraim Peabody, then the right hand of Fellowship by the Rev Edward Everett Hale, then a Hymn by Charles Sprague Esqr. then an Address to the Society by Revd. George Putnam D.D. then a concluding prayer by the Revd. N. G. Thomas then a closing Hymn a Doxology from

lg.l: “From All that dwell below the skies”—

div.p: then the Benediction by the Pastor himself, according to Custom. The solemnities had commenced at 1/2 past two oclock, it was near six when they closed. The Church was very crowded and the weather oppressively warm. I had been part of the time apprehensive of fainting, but made out to get through and immediately to return home, in the Carriage which took Mr. Lunt home. There had been several strangers here visitors from the State of Michigan and in the evening my Son and his wife were here.

I had been apprehensive that the fatigue of attending the Solemnities of the Ordination at the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society at Roxbury would have been too much for my feeble state of health, and would have been followed by a distressed
and unquiet night. But in this I was favourably disappointed as I had a very quiet night succeeded by a comfortable day. Mrs. Charles Adams, with her daughter, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa went to Boston this morning to return to dinner. President Quincy was here, and I informed him of the agreement I had made with Mr. Abbott Lawrence the day before yesterday to request President Edward Everett to appoint Tuesday the 21st. this month at ten oclock in the morning for a visitation of the Observatory at Cambridge by the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University—and I agreed to call on President Quincy at his house on that day, and that we will go together to be at Cambridge in the morning at ten oclock. I rode this afternoon with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Mary Cutts round the Quarries. We had Evening visits from Isaac Hull, and John Quincy— I make slow progress in my reading both of Dupuis Universelle Religion and in the anonymous Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— I find these books very dull. And to enliven the occupation I propose to add the perusal of the Articles Telescope and Glass in Rees Cyclopedia.

Mrs. Mary Catherine Adams birthday. Dr. Woodward was here this morning and I gave him an indifferent account of my condition of favorable improvement of which I have little encouragement to expect. I began reading the Articles Telescope and Glass, and immediately found myself ignorant beyond all conception. Even of the difference between flint glass and crown glass, and equally so, of that between Telescopes constructed upon the principles of Catoptics and those of Dioptics
For the time and opportunity to study all this the remainder of my life is not sufficient— The discoveries in practical Astronomy commencing with that of the Planet Uranus have all been dependent upon the improvement of the Instruments used for Astronomical Observations, that is enlarging by Artificial means the power of the Human eye, and if future discoveries, of the mechanism of the Universe all depend upon the extent to which the power of vision in the bodily frame of man may be enlarged. Of all the senses belonging to man it is by the sight alone that he can form conceptions of the structure of the Universe—from the other senses of Hearing, feeling, Smell, and taste, he can receive no assistance to convey intelligence to the mind and it would seem that his sight can be enlarged only by the means of instruments of glass— Until the year 1785—all the researches of the human mind in Astronomy had only discovered its own delusions respecting the Solar system and its own errors in trusting for thousands of years to the movements of the Heavenly bodies as they appear to the naked eye—all totally different to the ostensible Reports of the daily changes of day and night— I took a ride this afternoon with Miss Louisa. C. Smith and Miss Mary Cutts round Milton returning by the Neponset road— My son was here in the Evening—

I wrote yesterday to President Edward Everett requesting him to appoint Tuesday 21st. of this month for the visitation of the Observatory by the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University—and this morning I received a Letter from my niece Susan B. Treadway, from Richmond Virginia of the 7th. inst enclosing an order from the Bank of Virginia upon the
Bank of America of New York for one hundred and ten dollars, in part payment of a loan of two hundred dollars which she had made last September— I received also a Letter from W. W. Brown second assistant Postmaster General concerning the Post Office at West Wrentham in this County—which will require an answer. a Letter also from N Sargent Philadelphia of the sixth instt. appraising me that he proposes to be a Candidate for the appointment of Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States at the approaching Session of Congress but my vote is already promised if called to give it to Mr. B. B. French the Clerk of the last Congress— The storm of rain continuing the whole day prevented my taking my usual ride this afternoon. and we had no company in the evening—

The storm of rain continued all night and in showers through the day The Rev Siras. A. Bartol Colleague Pastor with the Rev Dr. Charles Lowell at the West line Street Congregational Church Boston preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt— His morning text was from Romans 1.20. For the invisible things of him from the creation of the World are clearly seen being understood by the things that are made even his eternal power and God head—and Romans 2.15. [“]Which shew the work of the Law written in their hearts their conscience also bearing witness and their thoughts the mean while accusing or else excusing one another. 16. In the day when God shall judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ according to my Gospel”— The practise of taking double texts seems to have become a Fashion among the younger Clergymen of the Trinitarian Denomination. I somewhat doubt its
propriety; it leads to the complication of the theme of the Discourse— The subject of Mr. Bartols sermon was the foundation of Religious Belief and the correspondent human action, but from his double text he drew a three fold impulse upon the agony of man—first Nature, secondly duty, thirdly Revelation The Discourse was argumentative and the reasoning forcible. His delivery was cold, and inanimate. The Text of his Afternoon Sermon was 1. Corinthians 7.31—[“]And they that use this World, as not abusing it”— The Doctrine drawn from this Text was, that this World was made for the use of man, but a Religion and morality were given him to preserve him from abusing it— Mr. Bartol dined with us. His is a graduate of Bowdoin College of the year 1831. I was obliged to ride to and from Meeting morning and afternoon. The storm of rain continued till the night.

The Equinoxtial storm continued with heavy rain in the night and deprived me of the exercise both of walking and riding— It did not however deprive me of sleep nor of the power of reading in the day I confined it chiefly to the Universelle Religion par Dupuis— His system is that the source of all Religion including Christianity is the Worship of the Sun under various modified time, and he has long and tedious Commentaries upon the Deification of Hercules of Thesius and of Baccus— All degenerating into Fabulus Legions but all terminating in Astronomical phenomena—representing the annual course of the Sun connected with that of the moon. Dupuis is not the original inventor or discoverer of this System but he has spun it out into 12 or 14 volumes and with an array of antiquity never perhaps excuded— Col. George Bumford visited us, and dined with us, returning by the Cars to Boston after dinner at 1/2 past three oclock.

I had a quiet night and slept till daylight this morning, and found a clear sky, when I rose, with cool Autumnal weather. Elizabeth. C. Adams returned this day from her excursion to Saratoga and New York, where she has been passing some time with her friend Mrs. Bartlett— I continue my reading as usual of Dupuis Universelle Religion and the Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation Evening ride to Braintree—

This day at 12 oclock was the Annual Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund at Quincy. A Resolution had been adopted two years ago that the Annual Meeting should be held on the first Wednesday in September in the Select mens Room at the new Town Hall, and that if that day should by any accident pass over, without being held it should then be specially called as early in the month of September as might be. The first Wednesday of the month was passed over inattentively this year, but it was specially called by the President Mr. Thomas Greenleaf and was held this day— The members present were Thomas Greenleaf President, George. W. Beale, Charles. F. Adams and myself— Mr. Josiah Quincy Senior was not present. There was nothing to be done except the adjustment of the accounts of the Treasurer of the Corporation, who is also the Treasurer for the Town of Quincy, John Briesler— The Meeting adjourned before one oclock— There was another Meeting called a Pic Nic of children, otherwise a Temperance meeting
calling themselves a Cold Water Army who had a collation at the Town Hall— To this Meeting I was invited and witnessed their assemblage to the number of about one hundred and twenty children of each sex between seven and fourteen years of age, who formed a procession issuing from the Town Hall and returning there to their Collation.— to which I did not stay. They had sundry addresses made to them and were still there when I rode by, up to Braintree and returning by Bens Point about sunset—

Mrs. President Edward Everett came from Cambridge with her daughter, and Miss Barclay daughter of the British Consul at New York. Mr. Palfrey came and we all dined at my Sons house— After dinner they returned to Cambridge, and I rode with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts to Milton returning by the way of Neponset. Miss Sampson has been here since Tuesday. While I was absent seven Ladies and gentlemen by the name of Sleeper paid me a visit, I did not see them— Two persons from the State of Maine one named Robinson the other Vail, very complimentary, as are indeed all my visitors, strangers who come to see me from motives of curiosity. I am under great obligations to them all, but give them no better than lenten entertainment. There was a bright Northern Light this Evening followed by a bright day.

There was a bright Northern Light this Evening— The Northern Light is some times a prognostic of rain within twenty four hours and sometimes of a bright sky for two days at least as it has now been We have now almost
daily news of Battles and of the approach of our Army to the City of Mexico, and of Peace, which must immediately follow upon that event— My two last nights have not been so quiet and some that preceeded them. I walked this day round the long Square. I rode this Evening with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts to Braintree returning by the Bent’s Point Methodist Church. Dr. Woodward was here and somewhat modified his prescriptions My Granddaughter received a Letter from Mr. Christopher Hughes who is at Chester Springs in Pennsylvania, somewhat of an Invalid and part of the time perhaps as much indisposed as I am. His case is more full of hopes, but perhaps as precarious as my own.

A Clergyman by the name of Curtis from Milwaukie from the Territory or State of Wisconsin, came this morng. pedling a volume by I A Lapam entitled Wisconsin its Geography and Topography &c— For which he claimed three quarters of a dollar, and solicited a contribution for erecting a Congregational Church at Milwaukie. I took his book, but thought the people of Milwaukie had better build their own Congregational Church. He said there were large numbers there about erecting a Roman Catholic Church mostly Germans. A number of Roman Catholics from Germany as well as from Ireland, is very great, in our New Western States and in the course of a few years will outnumber all other Denominations. I had a very unquiet and dejected night and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa is also quite indisposed, with a severe cold. I rode this Evening with my wife and Mrs. Charles Adams round Braintree.

The Revd. Nathaniel Hall Minister of the Congregational Church Dorchester preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text was from Ecclesiastes 1.3 [“]What profit hath a man of all his labor which he taketh under the Sun”— The peculiarity of the Discourse was that it was an elaborate argument against the principle of the text itself maintaining, that there is profit in all the labor of man. The text of the afternoon was from Hebrews 6.5. “The powers of the world to come”—a theme of awful solemnity— Mr. Hall has no pretension to eloquence of manner, but his composition is very good— He dined with us, but we had no evening visitors—

The Revd. Calvin Durfee was here this morning with his son a boy of ten or eleven years of age—he brought with him an Album in which I had written some things concerning my birth and lineage to which he requested me now to make an addition, which I accordingly did— Shortly before we had dined Mr. Joshua Dodge heretofore Consul of the United States at Bremen, and afterwards an Agent for negotiating with the Germanic Princes concerning duties upon Tobacco, came having already dined before he left Boston but remained and took Tea with us. Mr. Charles Sumner, and Mr. Ellis Gray Loring also came out after dinner took Tea with us and the three gentlemen returned by the Cars of six oclock. I walked round the long square before dinner but was obliged to retire part of the afternoon to my Couch— My son was here in the Eveg— Mr. Sumner and
Mr. Loring left with me a draft of a Letter, which they proposed to me to write containing sundry enquiries to be addressed with the consent of the British Government to the Governors of all their West India Colonies, requesting statements of their actual condition consequent upon the abolition of Slavery in each of the Islands— I received the paper with a promise to take it into consideration, but suggesting some difficulties which I thought there would be, to my entering into such a correspondence. I received also a Letter from Joseph Follensby heretofore Door Keeper to the House of Representatives of the House of Representatives stating that he proposes offering himself as a Candidate for that Office and asking my favorable consideration, to which he is fully entitled. I received also, a Letter from Mrs. Waterhouse repeating her request heretofore made for Letters received by me, from her husband during his life time. My Son was here, and told me that President Edward Everett was sick in bed, and could of course not attend at the meeting tomorrow of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory—

Rain great part of the night, and part of this morng I had a very indifferent night. I took it for granted that Mr. Quincy would not be able to attend at the Meeting of the Committee on the Observatory. that President Everett would be equally disabled and the weather being very unpromising I reluctantly renounced the attempt to go The weather was very equivocal all day between storm and sunshine, but I
walked round the long Square before dinner. I read besides my usual portion of Dupuis Universelle Religion the projected Letter upon British Emancipation left with me by Mr. Charles Sumner and Mr. Ellis. G. Loring.

The weather cleared off and we had a fine day— I went in the Carriage to Boston with Mrs. C. F. Adams, Miss Louisa C. Smith, and Miss Cutts, stopt of the way at Mr. Quincy house—he had been at my house yesterday afternoon, but I was lying down and did not see him. Not knowing whether the members of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Boston had visited the Observatory yesterday or not—this was first to be ascertained— I left the Carriage in Summer Street and walked to the Counting house of Abbott and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street, but Mr Abbott Lawrence was not there neither did I see him— He was attending a meeting of the Directors of a Seamans Saving Bank where I endeavored to find him but without success. I went to my sons Office No 23. Court St. and found a number of gentlemen there in consultation with him prepatory to a meeting of a State Convention of the Whigs to be held at Springfield on the 29th. of this month. While there I received from Mr. J. Ingersoll Bowditch the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of the Observatory, made yesterday and signed by Messrs David Sears, Abbott Lawrence, J Ingersoll Bowditch and Francis Peabody, who actually met—received the Reports of the Perkins Professor of Astronomy and mathematics—Pearce and of the Observer W. C. Bond and made the Report to the Board of Overseers, to be submitted at the session of the Legislature next Winter. From my Sons Office I proceeded, to the Revd. Dr. N. L. Frothinghams, where I had agreed to meet the ladies, to return to Quincy— I found Dr. Frothingham
at home but he was obliged to go out at one oclock to a christening— I could have but a very short conversation with him and at half past one we left his house and returned to Quincy— My son and his daughter Louisa went this Evening to Boston to the Opera. and we were left at home. Isaac. Hull. Adams. dined with us; and Elizabeth Adams was here last Evening. I received a Letter from H. G. Sommerby, who proposes to go to England, to investigate the pedigrees of the early settlers of New England— I read the Report of the Committee who visited the Observatory yesterday and the Reports of the Perkins Professor and of the Observer William. C. Bond to them, deeply regretting my failure to attend at the meeting and that of Mr. Quincy consequent upon mine— There is yet one Astronomical Instrument to be received from England and mounted for the complete organization of the Observatory—

After a somewhat restless and uneasy night, I was enabled to take my usual walk this morning— A man by the name of John Smith a Quaker from the Island of Barbadoes came as a mendicant for assistance to return to that Island—with a certificate from Henry Baker of Providence Rhode Island and recommending him as a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church Before he was gone came Capt Matthias Rich from Cape Cod, blind, with his son a boy of ten or twelve years of age and with a recommendaty Certificate from Dr. Reynolds of Boston— Of this Class of Certificated mendicants scarcely one day ever passes but one or more presents himself, and of that sort of beggary I believe there is at least as much in this Country as in any part of Europe— The greater number of them are Europeans
but there is no scarcity of them natives of our own Soil— I had also a visit from Mr. Whitney who has before Congress, a Petition and project for the construction of a Railway from Lake Michigan to the South Sea in the Territory of Oregon— He presented it first I think at the first Session of the last Congress and reports favorable to it, were made at the last Session of Congress— I was in favor of it myself and gave it what encouragement I could— He bespoke my influence in favor of it still, and entered into some details upon which I told him I could not as yet form any decided opinion but which I should not be found disposed to meet with unreasonable objections— He spent as much as two hours with me in discussing his own peculiar views on the subject, but in favor of which I could only promise a good will— I attended this Evening the Party given by Mr. & Mrs. Lunt to their whole parish and of which he gave the invitation in the Pulpit last Sunday. I remained there about an hour. The house was crowded with the Company, with a small portion of which I was personally acquainted; among them some whom I have known from my earliest childhood— We came home between nine and ten oclock in the Evening—

Miss Cutts went to Boston and dined at Dr. Warrens, and returned by the Cars at 6. Oclock. Mrs. John Adams was confined the whole day to her bed by indisposition. Mrs. J. Q. Adams, C. F. Adams his wife, Louisa Catherine and Mary Louisa went to Boston this afternoon in the Carriage to see the Italian Opera of Hernani— They got home about half past eleven at night.

I propose, to examine my Files of Papers, and to minute down in this Diary those which I shall
successively examine and for which I shall ask the assistance of my Grand daughter. The Revd. Samuel K. Lothrop came and introduced a Mr. Hincks an native of Ireland but who comes as a . . . from London. Mr. Hincks returned to Boston by the Railway Cars but Mr. Lothrop returned to his Summer residence on Milton Hill. I walked round the Long Square but was disappointed of my evening ride— Continued reading in the Universelle Religion of Dupuis which leads me deeper and deeper into confusion—

A stormy day and night. Mr. Lunt preached to very thin auditory—his morng text was from Mark 3.1. [“]And he entered again into the Synagogue and there was a man there which had a withered hand”— This was the occasion upon they watched Jesus whether he would heal the man’s withered hand on the Sabbath day—their purpose being to make it a charge against him He did heal the man’s hand and the Pharisees took counsel with the Herodians how they might destroy him. He had in defence of himself laid down as the real law sanctifying, the Sabbath that the sabbath was made for man—and not man for the Sabbath that it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath-day, putting it to them in the form of a question which they dared not answer— He recurred to the example of David whom he considered as justified in a double violation of the Levitical Law, not only by eating to appease his hunger but by taking the shewbread which none but the Priests were obliged to eat. Mr. Lunt did not much enlarge upon this point of view but rather dilated by a description of the great power conferred upon man by the exercise of the hand, and the great abridgment of all the powers of man when deprived of the use of hand— The afternoon
text was from Matthew 13.18. “Hear ye therefore the parable of the sower.” One of the many Discourses upon which the moral principles of Christianity were founded. Lieut Joseph. H. Adams who is stationed at Charlestown came and dined with us, but the foul weather confined all our Ladies at home.

Another stormy Night and day— Jonathan Cummings paid me a morning visit before our Breakfast, though he himself had Breakfasted at his Sons house which formerly belonged to Anthony Baxter Mr. Cummings the Father lives at Plymouth on the Merrimac River in the County of Grafton in the State of New Hampshire He was born at Concord in that same State in 1774. the first year of the Revolutionary War. His father removed not long afterwards to his present residence which at that time was in the midst of a wilderness, though now in the center of . . . Railroads I received a Letter from Joseph N. Brewer of the City of Roxbury enclosing a Report made by Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn the mayor to the City Council of this City in favor of a Public Cemetery— A Letter from Freeman Hunt Editor of the Merchant’s Magazine a Periodical publication requesting me for a Certificate of my opinion in favor of that work. And one from R. C. Washington of Washington announcing himself as a Candidate for the Office of Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives of the United States— I walked before dinner round the short Railway square not without being overtaken by a shower of rain. I rode in the Evening with Mrs. Charles Adams and Miss Cutts round Milton Hill. My Son was afterwards here in the Evening—

A man by the name of Peter D Waldelaar, came
as a mendicant claiming to be a relation of Mr. Van Vechten of Albany— He claimed also to be coming now from the State of Ohio and solicited contribution for some Public Institution the object of which he could not explain. He took however a refusal very quietly and departed I received from the Revd. William. D. Sprague D.D. a Discourse on the death of the Hon Silas Wright late Governor of the State of New York delivered in the 2d. Presbyterian Church at Albany on the 5th. of the present month. Mr: Wright died of apoplexy on theday of August. The storm subsided. I walked round the long Square before dinner. Ride to South Braintree and Weymouth with Mrs. Charles. Miss Cutts left us to take Tea with Elizabeth. C. Adams. My son stays over night in Boston to go early tomorrow morning to the Whig State Convention at Springfield.

I received a Letter from John. C. King a Sculptor who in the Summer of 1845. model’d my Bust at Boston. He complains that he had only eight subscribers for casts but that an Italian Pedlar he fears has got one of them and is pirating copies of it at a cheaper price than he can afford He desires an improvement of the Patent Laws extending to Sculptors, the privileges granted to Authors and asks for my written opinion of my Bust made by him. I walked round the Square before dinner, and afterwards rode with Mrs. John Adams and Mrs. Charles with her little Mary to the Biscuit Bakers at Milton. Mrs. Charles Adams spent the Evening here.

list.item: Mr. Daniel McBride Graham Professor of the Michigan Central

div.p: College an Institution of three years standing, came with a Letter introductory from the Reverend John Pierce of Brookline. Mr. D. Graham is on his first visit to New England to present the claims of his Seminary to Public favor— Mr. Jenkins of Roxbury came with him. I declined a contribution to the Central College of Michigan but gave him at his request an Autograph Signature. I received a Letter from J. W. Johnson dated Dartmouth College Hanover New Hampshire 25 September 1847 requesting an Autograph, with a swelling compliment. I walked round the long Square before dinner and dined with Mrs. Charles Adams, with the expectation that my son would have returned from Springfield, but he did not reach home till after dinner. A Mrs. Hale from Weathersfield Connecticut paid us a visit with her son Joseph Hale, who resides at Boston, her visit was one of curiosity We had also visits from Mrs. G. T. Bigelow and her brother Charles Miller who proposes to embark tomorrow in the Steamer Britania for England. I rode with Mrs Charles F. Adams and Mrs. John Adams round to Milton returning by the Neponset Bridge Turnpike. My Son and his wife passed the Evening with us.
